huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION:
It is such a large area that hunter competition is really low.  I would put a significant effort into pre-season scouting on this unit.  Don’t be afraid to ask the oil field workers where they have been seeing pronghorn.  They drive the roads that go right through prime antelope habitat every day and can be a great resource.  

I would work on locating water sources, placing trail cameras, and selecting a site for a ground blind.  Unless it rains which has been a rare occurrence, antelope have to come to water.  It is an extremely fun hunt, and you can see antelope all throughout the day.  Spot and stalk techniques are effective as well.  The pronghorn are used to vehicle traffic because of all the oil and gas production in the area.  They rely on their eye sight and speed to avoid predation.  As long as they don’t see anything out of the ordinary they are fairly docile, and calm.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: This is a very remote location with some areas with limited access.  Cellular phone coverage is very spotty on this hunt unit.  Digital cell phones may show several bars but cannot always connect due to the distance to the cell towers.  Satellite phones do work in the area.  The biologist suggests hand held radios and even a "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety.  Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightning, and hot conditions.  Storms can cause muddy road conditions and flash floods in this region.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 72.7~425~385~~~2.0–3.0~3.7~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Location of harvest:  The Vernal antelope herd does not show many signs of migration.  Throughout the year they stay in the same general area.  During the rut the larger herds tend to break up into smaller herds with one to two bucks in the herd.  The great thing about hunting antelope is that you can hunt them all throughout the day.  

Vegetative communities that dominate the areas of the herd unit frequented by pronghorn include salt desert shrub types on the lower elevation zones grading upward in elevation to Wyoming sage habitats.  Annual precipitation generally varies from 6 to 8 inches in these vegetation types.  Forb production is important for healthy fawn survival.  Water distribution can be limiting but has been provided by the BLM and other conservation interests through guzzlers or other devices.  During the past decade of drought, the poor maintenance condition of many of these artificial water sources limited their effectiveness.  Repairs have been made and are continuing.  

Natural gas and oil production is rapidly increasing on pronghorn range with subsequent vegetative removal limiting both forage availability and habitat effectiveness.  Habitat loss and disturbance associated with drilling and other energy extraction activities may be a significant factor affecting pronghorn populations.  I have seen antelope shade up during the day under the large tanks on oil well pads.  

I would focus on rangeland that boarder’s private agricultural land.  During late summer agricultural fields are essential for large herds of antelope.  The Ashlee Oil Field holds large groups of antelope.  Hwy 88 near the Hwy 40 intersection is a great place to look.  North of the Green River there are large salt desert shrub communities.

Scouting Tips:
A good spotting scope and binoculars are essential.  Scouting is most effective right before the hunt opens.  I would plan on covering a lot of ground to locate springs and guzzlers in the more arid areas on the northern part of the unit.  Trail cameras can make a big difference in scouting these areas.  Once you locate a buck there is a good chance he will stay in same vicinity.   

Behavior:  Antelope are fairly solitary, and herd up in small groups during the rut.  Bucks like to make scrapes in the dirt roads to make territories and warn off other competing bucks.  I don’t see large herds of antelope on this unit.  A large group of antelope in the Book Cliffs is 12-18 head.  They have to stay relatively close to a sustainable water source.  If it rains they are less likely to visit springs or guzzlers and more likely to drink out of hoof prints or natural water catches.

huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: click here or call 1-800-221-0659 to report your harvest. You must report your harvest, even if you did not take an animal, within 30 days of the season end date that is printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you not being able to apply for big game species in subsequent years. Submitting teeth or other biological samples from your animal, or having your animal checked by a DWR representative or CWMU operator does NOT fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of land is managed by the BLM.  There is a significant amount of SITLA land.  There are several DWR Wildlife Management Areas (WMA).  These areas are managed for wildlife and you can hunt on all these areas.  There is private land and some of it is accessible through the DWR’s Walk-in-Access Program (http://wildlife.utah.gov/walkinaccess/).
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
Please direct all questions regarding maps and camping regulations to the Vernal BLM Field Office (http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/vernal.html)
BLM:  14 day camping limit and you have to move 30 miles after 14 days.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: USGS 1:100,000 Vernal and Dutch John topo maps or BLM version equivalent that shows land onweership.
huntBoundaryInfos.COUNTY_ROAD_INFO:
County Road Access information:
Uintah County:  http://www.co.uintah.ut.us/roads/roaddept.php
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, and SITLA, and the regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans.  Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Vernal BLM Field Office, and SITLA.

Suggested Maps: BLM: Vernal, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads.  There are several county signs and BLM signs to help direct you.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: The boundary excludes all of the Tribal Trust Lands.  There is a large area of Ute Tribal Trust land to the west of the hunt unit.  Road access across the Tribal land is permitted using county roads.  All ATVs are prohibited on Tribal Lands; they must be trailered on access roads across Tribal lands.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Daggett and Uintah counties-—Boundary begins at the Dry Fork-Whiterocks drainage divide and the Daggett-Uintah county line (summit of the Uinta Mountains); east along the summit of the Uinta Mountains to US-191; north along US-191 to Cart Creek; north along Cart Creek to Flaming Gorge Reservoir; east along Flaming Gorge Reservoir to the Green River; east along the Green River to Gorge Creek; south along Gorge Creek to the USFS/private land boundary at the head of Davenport Draw; south along the USFS/private land boundary on the west side of Davenport Draw to the BLM boundary; south along the BLM boundary approximately one-third of a mile to the rim of Diamond Mountain;south and easterly along this rim until the rim intersects the Diamond Mountain road (Jones Hole Road); southwest along this road to the Brush Creek road; south along this road to the Island Park/Rainbow Park road; east along this road to the Dinosaur National Monument boundary; northeast along this boundary to the Utah-Colorado state line; south along this state line to the Green River; south along this river to the Duchesne River; north along this river to the Uinta River; north along this river to Whiterocks River; north along this river to the East Fork of the Whiterocks River; north along this river to Whiterocks Lake and USFS Trail #025; northeast on this trail to the Dry Fork-Whiterocks drainage divide; north atop this divide to the Daggett-Uintah county line (summit of the Uinta Mountains). EXCLUDING ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Dutch John, Vernal. Boundary questions? Call the Vernal office, 435-781-9453.
